Best Bet
Its roots date to the early 1900's, but today the Hampton Classic Horse Show marks its 25th anniversary in its current incarnation with the opening of a week's run in Bridgehampton.

Its appeal is a toss-up between watching 1,200 horses (and their riders, who include members of the United States Equestrian Team) compete for $500,000 in prize money, or watching the East End celebrities the show attracts.

With action on five rings and, yes, an Instinet Cyber Cafe where visitors can check their e-mail, the show's highlights include today's ''World of the Horse'' at 1 p.m., after classes for youngsters under 8; free visits to the boutiques and exhibition tents tomorrow, when there is no competition; Seniors Day on Thursday, when those over 60 will be admitted free; the $25,000 Prudential World Cup and Grand Prix Qualifying Class on Friday; Kids Day on Saturday, when the $25,000 Sally Hansen Grand Prix tops the contests; and the four major events next Sunday, topped by the $150,000 Crown Royal Grand Prix.
The show is held on Snake Hollow Road from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. (631) 537-3177.
Happy Holiday Weekend
When it comes to Labor Day weekend festivities, old is in.
In terms of longevity, two events claim supremacy: the Hicksville Fire Department's Invitational Motorized Drill and the Shinnecock Pow-Wow.

With 30 departments from New York State competing, the Hicksville drill offers its 72nd edition with a parade at 5 p.m. next Sunday and the competitions at 9 a.m. on Labor Day at the department's course on West Barclay Street (516) 933-6444.

The pow-wow, on the Shinnecock Reservation, off Route 27A in Southampton, makes its 54th annual appearance Friday through Monday, welcoming 60 tribes from the United States, Mexico and Central America who will dance, sing and share their crafts and foods, with grand entry parades at 6 p.m. Friday, noon and 6 p.m. Saturday and Sunday, and noon Monday (631) 283-6143.
There are two debuts.

In Old Bethpage, at the Village Restoration on Round Swamp Road, there is a Harvest Musical Festival 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday through Monday with parlor music, traditional folk tunes, 19th-century dances, performances by the Old Bethpage Singers and the Village Military Brass Sextet and teams from the 1867 and 1887 leagues playing ''Old Time Base Ball'' at 2 p.m. Saturday and Monday and 11 a.m. and 2 p.m. Sunday (516) 572-8400.

In Kings Park, the Nissequogue River State Park, the newest state park on Long Island, gets into the holiday swing of things with a Back to School Festival. From 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday and Sunday there will be family activities like face painting, games and enviromental programs. Park admission is $5 a car (631) 669-1000, Ext. 247.
Season Finales
All good things must come to an end, and this week the free summer park concerts complete their runs.

Today, the action begins with the Jazz Alliance Sextet appearing at 2 p.m. in the final Islip Arts Council concert at Bayard Cutting Arboretum (631) 224-5420. In Port Washington, the Project, a Long Island-based show band, ends North Hempstead's programming at 1 p.m. at Bar Beach (516) 327-3110. Tonight at 8 there are three concerts: in Glen Cove, where the Atlantic Wind Concert Band plays at Morgan Park (516) 759-6970; in Stony Brook, where Paddy Doyle's Boots offers traditional Irish music at the Village Center (631) 751-2244; and in Wantagh, where Manhattan Rhapsody performs contempory music at the Jones Beach State Park Boardwalk Bandshell (516) 785-2420.

It's Israeli-American Night at 8 tomorrow night with the Wholesale Klezmer Band and other performers at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow (516) 572-0223, while Tuesday night brings South Bound, a country ensemble, to the New York Beach boardwalk in Long Beach at 8 (516) 431-3890. On Wednesday, music fans Out East have the Thunder Lizard Singers at 8 p.m. at the Town Green in Southold (631) 765-3598, or Vivian and the Merrymakers, a steel band, at 6:45 p.m. in Agawam Park in Southampton (631) 287-4377.

Thursday features ''A Musical Revue with Ferretti and Clark'' at 7 p.m. at the Freeport Village Hall Courtyard (516) 223-2522, or the American Concert Band at 7:30 p.m. on the Village Green in Westhampton Beach (631) 288-0780.
And on Saturday Ken Morr closes the Long Beach series at 8 p.m. at the National Beach boardwalk, and Dog Soldiers plays rock and rhythm 'n' blues at 8 p.m. at the Jones Beach Boardwalk Bandshell.
Exhibitions End

Some museums also keep summer hours. Two in Southold close next Sunday: The Southold Indian Museum on Bayview Avenue, which is run by a chapter of the New York State Archeological Association and has exhibits of American Indian baskets and wood carvings of leaders like Geronimo and Chief Joseph (631) 765-5577; and the Southold Historical Society's Summer Gallery in the Ann Currie-Bell House on Main Road, which is showing 55 hand-woven pieces from the Paumanok Weavers Guild (631) 765-5500. The museums are open this afternoon and next Saturday and Sunday.
Honoring Benny Goodman

Ray Alexander, a jazz vibraphonist and drummer who has worked with such legends as Claude Thornhill and George Shearing, brings his quintet to Southold today to offer ''A Tribute to Benny Goodman.'' The concert, to benefit the Southold Historical Society Lighthouse Museum, is at 4 p.m. at the Horton Point Lighthouse which, along with the Nautical Museum, will be open to visitors starting at 11:30 a.m. (631) 765-5500.
'Deirdre' Legend

Joined by dancers from Mise Eire, the school of Irish dance in Babylon, the East End Special Players tackle ''The Legend of Deirdre'' tomorrow at the Guild Hall John Drew Theater in East Hampton. Combining improvisation with live music and dance, the Special Players, who have developmental problems, will recreate a romantic ancient Irish folk tale about a Druid's prophecy that ''a child of astonishing beauty would be born into a kingdom and her name shall be Deirdre.'' The performance, at 7 p.m., will benefit the Child Development Center of the Hamptons and will be repeated on Sept. 28 at the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center. (631) 267-6132.
Baldwin in Reading

Tomorrow night in Sag Harbor, Alec Baldwin heads a star cast in a reading of Paddy Chayefsky's ''Latent Heterosexual'' at 8, at the Bay Street Theater. Written in 1967, the dark comedy, about a homosexual author who marries for tax purposes, was the playwright's final work. In addition to Mr. Baldwin, the reading, which is directed by Bob Balaban, features F. Murray Abraham, Katie Finneran, Larry Keith and Mr. Balaban. (631) 725-9500.
Free Choices

TODAY -- The free Sunday tours at Brookhaven National Laboratory, which run from from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., end with a look at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider, an atom smasher that allows physicists to explore the origins of matter and the most basic structure of the universe. The lab is off William Floyd Parkway in Upton. (631) 344-2651.

TOMORROW -- Bob Shapiro, a member of the International Society of Appraisers, holds an antiques appraisal program at 6:30 p.m. at the Lindenhurst Library on Lee Avenue, evaluating one item each from audience members. Registration: (631) 957-7755.

FRIDAY -- ''Astronomy Open Night,'' a monthly series at the State University at Stony Brook, returns with a look at ''The Latest News on Black Holes and Gravitational Lenses.'' The lecture, by Prof. F. Douglas Swest, a member of the physics and astronomy faculty, will be at 7:30 p.m. in Room 001 of the ESS Building. (631) 632-8100.
